prompt.p: A 48-year-old woman attends the Emergency Department 5 days after thyroidectomy with perioral and hand tingling. On examination Chvostek's sign is positive.
Which of the following investigations is most likely to be abnormal given the patient's symptoms and signs?

modalFeedback.p: Option C (Serum calcium) is C orrect. Thyroid surgery can result in damage to the parathyroid gland(s), which regulate calcium metabolism.
Option A (Full blood count) is Incorrect. Full blood count would indicate the presence of postoperative anaemia or infection.
Option B (Liver function tests) is Incorrect. Liver function tests would not be affected by thyroid surgery or parathyroid dysfunction.
Option D (Serum glucose) is Incorrect. The patient's symptoms and signs do not indicate a glucose disorder.
Option E (Thyroid function tests) is Incorrect. Hypothyroidism can cause carpal tunnel syndrome and hand tingling, but would not cause a positive Chvostek's sign.
